definition: a prescribed guide for conduct or action
the laws or regulations prescribed by the founder of a religious order for observance by its members
an accepted procedure, custom, or habit
a usually written order or direction made by a court regulating court practice or the action of parties
a legal precept or doctrine
a regulation or bylaw governing procedure or controlling conduct
a usually valid generalization

a generally prevailing quality, state, or mode                                      
             
             fair weather was the rule yesterday
a standard of judgment : criterion
a regulating principle
a determinate method for performing a mathematical operation and obtaining a certain result
the exercise of authority or control : dominion
a period during which a specified ruler or government exercises control
a strip of material marked off in units used especially for measuring : ruler sense 3, tape measure
a metal strip with a type-high face that prints a linear design
for the most part : generally

to exert control, direction, or influence on                                      
             
             the passions that rule our minds

to exercise control over especially by curbing or restraining                                      
             
             rule a fractious horse

to exercise authority or power over often harshly or arbitrarily                                      
             
             the speaker ruled the legislature with an iron hand
to be preeminent in : dominate
to determine and declare authoritatively
to mark with lines drawn along or as if along the straight edge of a ruler
to mark (a line) on a paper with a ruler
to arrange in a line
to exercise supreme authority

to be first in importance or prominence : predominate                                      
             
             the physical did not rule in her nature
to exist in a specified state or condition
to lay down a legal rule

to be extremely cool or popular                                      
                
                  —used as a generalized term of praise or approval          for a little attitude at the right price, sneakers rule— Tish Hamilton
a statement that tells you what is or is not allowed in a particular game, situation, etc.
a statement that tells you what is allowed or what will happen within a particular system (such as a language or science)
a piece of advice about the best way to do something
to have control and power over a country, area, group, etc.
to have great influence over (someone)
to make a legal decision about something

a guide or principle for conduct or action                                      
             
             To play this game, you need to follow the rules.

an accepted or usual method, custom, or habit                                      
             
             "I'm a pretty quiet creature as a rule," said the horse …

the exercise of authority or control : government                                      
                

            The country was under British rule.
ruler sense 2
to exercise authority over : govern

control entry 1 sense 1, direct                                      
             
             Don't let emotions rule your decision.

to be supreme or outstanding in                                      
             
             He rules the tennis courts.

to give or state as a considered decision                                      
                

            The judge ruled that the evidence could not be used.
to mark with lines drawn along the straight edge of a ruler
a regulating principle or precept

an order or directive issued by a court in a particular proceeding especially upon petition of a party to the proceeding that commands an officer or party to perform an act or show cause why an act should not be performed                                      
             
             a rule directing the district court to show cause why its ruling should not be vacated

a usually judicially promulgated regulation having the force of law that governs judicial practice or procedure                                      
             
             rules of evidence
rule of law sense 1

all or part of a statement (as a regulation) by an administrative agency that has general or particular applicability and future effect and that is designed to implement, interpret, or prescribe law or policy or that describes the organization, procedure, or practice of the agency itself                                      
             
             a rule subject to statutory notice and comment requirements for informal rulemaking
a regulation or bylaw governing procedure or conduct in a body, organization, institution, or proceeding
a resolution of a legislative rules committee setting forth the terms for consideration of a particular bill by the entire body

the exercise of authority or control                                      
             
             majority rule
to exercise authority or power over

to lay down a rule or ruling                                      
             
             ruled in favor of the plaintiff
in: fair weather was the rule yesterday
the passions that rule our minds
rule a fractious horse
ruled his appetites firmly

for a little attitude at the right price, sneakers rule
obey the law
the rules of the game
regulations affecting nuclear power plants
the precepts of effective writing
a statute requiring the use of seat belts
a city ordinance
the canons of good taste
she decided to sell her house
determined the cause of the problem
the dean's decision settled the campus alcohol policy
the judge ruled that the evidence was inadmissible
he resolved to quit smoking

definition: a statement explaining what someone can or cannot do in a particular system, game, or situation
Verbs
a statement or principle that describes the ways in which the words in a language can be used and combined
the person, country, political or religious group etc that officially controls or governs a place
a ruler
in: We need new club rules before we start looking for more members.
rule of: the basic rules of the game
break a rule  (=not obey a rule): Anyone who breaks the rules will face disciplinary action.
follow/obey a rule: You should always follow these simple rules when using electrical equipment.
against the rules: You can’t do that, it’s against the rules!
rules and regulations: They complain that businesses are being hampered by too many rules and regulations.
complicated grammatical rules
British rule over Hong Kong ended in 1997.
The country was in tatters after 13 years of Conservative rule.
as a rule
be the rule
bend/stretch the rules
make it a rule to do something
rule of law
rule of thumb
rules are rules
work to rule

definition: an accepted principle or instruction that states the way things are or should be done, and tells you what you are allowed or are not allowed to do:
a period of time during which a particular person or group is in control of a country:
to control or be the person in charge of something such as a country:
to be the most important and controlling influence on someone:
to decide officially:
to draw a straight line using something that has a straight edge:
control:
to control, or be the person in charge of a country:
to allow the rules to be broken in a way that is not very serious:
a practical and approximate way of measuring or deciding about something:
the set of ideas and principles that most people involved in an activity, area of business, etc. accept and follow:
used to say that a particular condition or way of operating is typical or accepted in a particuar situation:
in: A referee must know all the rules of the game.
